content: This post describes what Compose recomposition is and how to optimize your Compose code to minimize recompositions.
description: This post describes what Compose recomposition is and how to optimize your Compose code to minimize recompositions.
excerpt_html: This post describes what Compose recomposition is and how to optimize your Compose code to minimize recompositions.
excerpt_text: This post describes what Compose recomposition is and how to optimize your Compose code to minimize recompositions.
html: This post describes what Compose recomposition is and how to optimize your Compose code to minimize recompositions.
summary:
What is recomposition A Compose function in Jetpack Compose represents some UI to be rendered:
@Composable fun UsersScreen() { var usersScreenState by remember { mutableStateOf( UsersScreenState( title = "Users", body = "This is the users screen", (1..40).toList().map { Person(it, "Firstname Lastname $it") }, ) ) } Column() { Text(usersScreenState.title) Text(usersScreenState.description) Button(onClick = { usersScreenState = usersScreenState.copy(title = Random.nextInt().toString()) }) { Text("Change title") } PersonList(usersScreenState.persons) } } Notice that the usersScreenState is a var which means it can change.
title: Jetpack Compose - Recompositions

content: This post describes various methods to use dependent objects in an Android ViewModel which depend on the viewModelScope.

html: This post describes various methods to use dependent objects in an Android ViewModel which depend on the viewModelScope.
summary:
Image by Dall-E: “Inside of a large factory assembling robots from parts. The scene is somewhat dark with neon lights. cyberpunk style.”
Context A ViewModel in Android (not to be confused with the term ViewModel in the MVVM architecture pattern) is a component scoped to the lifecycle of another component, usually a fragment or an activity. To create maintainable code without becoming the ViewModel to large, the ViewModel delegates to other objects.
title: Koin ViewModel Injection

content: This post describes various strategies on how to approach reusability in software products.
description: This post describes various strategies on how to approach reusability in software products.
excerpt_html: This post describes various strategies on how to approach reusability in software products.
excerpt_text: This post describes various strategies on how to approach reusability in software products.
html: This post describes various strategies on how to approach reusability in software products.
summary:
Re-usability within software development means to reuse (part of) a solution in different products with the aim of:
faster time to market lower costs less chance of introducing issues be able to use shared knowledge Re-usability at different abstraction levels Re-usability exists at many levels of abstraction in software development. Each abstraction offers some degree of advantages as well as disadvantages. Some examples, from high to low abstraction level:
Infrastructure Using infrastructure to distribute software.
title: Code re-usability

content: This post describes various strategies that can be used whena adopting KMM for native Android and iOS development.
description: This post describes various strategies that can be used whena adopting KMM for native Android and iOS development.
excerpt_html: This post describes various strategies that can be used whena adopting KMM for native Android and iOS development.
excerpt_text: This post describes various strategies that can be used whena adopting KMM for native Android and iOS development.
html: This post describes various strategies that can be used whena adopting KMM for native Android and iOS development.
summary:
KMM adoption strategies Introduction Kotlin multiplatform Mobile, in short KMM, lets you write native cross platform mobile applications. It lets you share logic across iOS and Android while still leveraging all of the native features of the platform.
There are several advantages of sharing code between platforms:
Reduced development time More consistent logic across platforms More consistent behavior across platforms Less bugs Improved team communication KMM gives the flexibility to decide what code is shared.
title: KMM adoption strategies

content: This post show how to add share localized resources and images between iOS and Android in KMM project.
description: This post show how to add share localized resources and images between iOS and Android in KMM project.
excerpt_html: This post show how to add share localized resources and images between iOS and Android in KMM project.
excerpt_text: This post show how to add share localized resources and images between iOS and Android in KMM project.
html: This post show how to add share localized resources and images between iOS and Android in KMM project.
summary:
Introduction Kotlin Multiplatform Mobile (in short KMM) allows you to share a lot of code which is normally duplicated across iOS and Android native platforms. KMM does not mandate that certain type of code is shared, it is up to you. It also does not mandate any particular architecture.
Although KMM enables sharing of code between platforms it does not provide the ability to share localized string resources and images out-of-the box between iOS and Android.
title: Localized resources and images in KMM

content: This post show how to add basic support for casting images to a cast enabled receiver.
description: This post show how to add basic support for casting images to a cast enabled receiver.
excerpt_html: This post show how to add basic support for casting images to a cast enabled receiver.
excerpt_text: This post show how to add basic support for casting images to a cast enabled receiver.
html: This post show how to add basic support for casting images to a cast enabled receiver.
summary:
Full source code can be found here: https://github.com/jcraane/android-simple-image-cast
By adding Chromecast support to media rich apps like photo- and video players, users can display content to Chromecast enabled devices. This greatly enhances the user experience of those apps.
This post demonstrates how to integrate the Chromecast SDK to add cast support for casting images. The app displays a list of publicly available images using an image carousel. When the user scrolls through those images, the images are cast to a connected receiver.
title: Casting images with Chromecast

content: This post provides some example of using regular expressions with IntelliJ find and replace function.
description: This post provides some example of using regular expressions with IntelliJ find and replace function.
excerpt_html: This post provides some example of using regular expressions with IntelliJ find and replace function.
excerpt_text: This post provides some example of using regular expressions with IntelliJ find and replace function.
html: This post provides some example of using regular expressions with IntelliJ find and replace function.
summary:
IntelliJ (and all JetBrains ideas) support the ability to find and replace text using regular expressions. Regular expressions in this context can be very powerful. When you do not use regular expressions enough, it may take some time to come up with a correct regex, often looking at the docs or examples to find out how they work.
find/replace regex (and also regular find/replace) works particularly well when lots of replacements need to be made.
title: IntelliJ find and replace using regular expressions

content: There are several patterns you can use to test for not null on multiple variables. This post describes different methods of null checking multiple variables in Kotlin.
description: There are several patterns you can use to test for not null on multiple variables. This post describes different methods of null checking multiple variables in Kotlin.
excerpt_html: There are several patterns you can use to test for not null on multiple variables. This post describes different methods of null checking multiple variables in Kotlin.
excerpt_text: There are several patterns you can use to test for not null on multiple variables. This post describes different methods of null checking multiple variables in Kotlin.
html: There are several patterns you can use to test for not null on multiple variables. This post describes different methods of null checking multiple variables in Kotlin.
summary:
Although not-null, immutable variables with sensible defaults are often desired, it is not always the case. It is sometimes required to check if multiple variables are not null. This post describes several variants of how to do this when smart casts are not possible because the variables are mutable.
Consider the following example:
class Person() { var name: String? = null var age: Int? = null fun doSomething() { if (name !
title: Kotlin: Multi variable null check

content: In this tutorial we create a Lambda function which retrieves this data from the DynamoDB table and expose this functionality over HTTP using API Gateway.
description: In this tutorial we create a Lambda function which retrieves this data from the DynamoDB table and expose this functionality over HTTP using API Gateway.
excerpt_html: In this tutorial we create a Lambda function which retrieves this data from the DynamoDB table and expose this functionality over HTTP using API Gateway.

html: In this tutorial we create a Lambda function which retrieves this data from the DynamoDB table and expose this functionality over HTTP using API Gateway.
summary:
In the previous tutorial I showed you how to use AWS Lambda and API Gateway to insert items in a DynamoDB table. The example implemented a function which stored the location of the user. In this tutorial we create a Lambda function which retrieves this data from the DynamoDB table and expose this functionality over HTTP using API Gateway.
Create a DynamoDB Global Secondary Index
The DeviceLocation DynamoDB table uses the id as partition key.
title: AWS tutorial: DynamoDB part 2

content: In this post I am going through a full (Java) example of integrating AWS Lambda, DynamoDb and Api Gateway to create a function and expose this function as a HTTP resource for other parties to consume.

summary:
In this post I am going through a full (Java) example of integrating AWS Lambda, DynamoDb and Api Gateway to create a function and expose this function as a HTTP resource for other parties to consume.
Before we dive into the details I will give a brief overview of the AWS services used in this example (as taken from the AWS documentation):
AWS Lambda. AWS Lambda is a compute service that runs developers’ code in response to events and automatically manages the compute resources for them, making it easy to build applications that respond quickly to new information.
title: AWS tutorial: DynamoDB part 1

content: In this post I am going to show how to increase the max open files for Elastic Search on OSX.
description: In this post I am going to show how to increase the max open files for Elastic Search on OSX.
excerpt_html: In this post I am going to show how to increase the max open files for Elastic Search on OSX.
excerpt_text: In this post I am going to show how to increase the max open files for Elastic Search on OSX.
html: In this post I am going to show how to increase the max open files for Elastic Search on OSX.
summary:
Elastic Search, Logstash and Kibana (ELK) is an end-to-end stack which provides realtime analytics for almost any type of structured or unstructured data.
When importing large amounts of data using Logstash to Elastic Search (ES), the chances are that ES hit the limits of the maximum files it can open. This limit is seen as an error in the ES logs with the following description: (Too many open files)
To deal with this you can increase the maximum files ES (or any process) may open using the following steps:
title: Elastic Search max open files

content: Sometimes you run into a situation where you want to refactor some code bu
description: Sometimes you run into a situation where you want to refactor some code bu
excerpt_html: Sometimes you run into a situation where you want to refactor some code bu
excerpt_text: Sometimes you run into a situation where you want to refactor some code bu
html: Sometimes you run into a situation where you want to refactor some code bu
summary:
Sometimes you run into a situation where you want to refactor some code but cannot use the regular refactorings. For example, take the following code:
jQuery("body").on("change", "#fontSelector", "change", function () { var selectedFont = jQuery("#fontSelector").val(); layoutDesigner.selectFont(selectedFont); }); I wanted to replace the above code with the following:
jQuery("#fontSelector").off("change"); jQuery("#fontSelector").on("change", function () { var selectedFont = jQuery("#fontSelector").val(); layoutDesigner.selectFont(selectedFont); }); Sure, I could rewrite this manually. But this takes a long time with dozens of such event handling constructs, all with different selectors, events and functions.
title: IntelliJ structural search and replace

content: As some of you will know I am a huge fan of MyBatis. I have used it in a lot of projects and it never failed me. I like how you are in control of the SQL and the flexibility this brings by mapping result sets to classes instead of mapping tables to classes.
description: As some of you will know I am a huge fan of MyBatis. I have used it in a lot of projects and it never failed me. I like how you are in control of the SQL and the flexibility this brings by mapping result sets to classes instead of mapping tables to classes.
excerpt_html: As some of you will know I am a huge fan of MyBatis. I have used it in a lot of projects and it never failed me. I like how you are in control of the SQL and the flexibility this brings by mapping result sets to classes instead of mapping tables to classes.
excerpt_text: As some of you will know I am a huge fan of MyBatis. I have used it in a lot of projects and it never failed me. I like how you are in control of the SQL and the flexibility this brings by mapping result sets to classes instead of mapping tables to classes.
html: As some of you will know I am a huge fan of MyBatis. I have used it in a lot of projects and it never failed me. I like how you are in control of the SQL and the flexibility this brings by mapping result sets to classes instead of mapping tables to classes.
summary:
As some of you will know I am a huge fan of MyBatis. I have used it in a lot of projects and it never failed me. I like how you are in control of the SQL and the flexibility this brings by mapping result sets to classes instead of mapping tables to classes.
Recently I wanted to map some columns from a table to actual typed properties of an object, and some columns to a property of type Map within that same object.
title: MyBatis

content: Several techniques exist to create computer generated musical melodies. One of those techniques is genetic algorithms.
description: Several techniques exist to create computer generated musical melodies. One of those techniques is genetic algorithms.
excerpt_html: Several techniques exist to create computer generated musical melodies. One of those techniques is genetic algorithms.
excerpt_text: Several techniques exist to create computer generated musical melodies. One of those techniques is genetic algorithms.
html: Several techniques exist to create computer generated musical melodies. One of those techniques is genetic algorithms.
summary: Introduction Several techniques exist to create computer generated musical melodies. One of those techniques is genetic algorithms. Because the diversity of melodies over a specific range of notes is so large, genetic algorithms are a good candidate to help in composing melodies. This article describes how genetic algorithms can be used to compose musical melodies. this is explained following the steps needed to apply a genetic algorithm. These steps are:
title: Melody composition with genetic algorithms

content: Out of interest I am familiarizing myself in genetic algorithms, in short GA. My interest in GA came when I first heard about the JGAP project.
description: Out of interest I am familiarizing myself in genetic algorithms, in short GA. My interest in GA came when I first heard about the JGAP project.
excerpt_html: Out of interest I am familiarizing myself in genetic algorithms, in short GA. My interest in GA came when I first heard about the JGAP project.
excerpt_text: Out of interest I am familiarizing myself in genetic algorithms, in short GA. My interest in GA came when I first heard about the JGAP project.
html: Out of interest I am familiarizing myself in genetic algorithms, in short GA. My interest in GA came when I first heard about the JGAP project.
summary: Out of interest I am familiarizing myself in genetic algorithms, in short GA. My interest in GA came when I first heard about the JGAP project. As mentioned on the project’s site “JGAP (pronounced “jay-gap”) is a Genetic Algorithms and Genetic Programming component provided as a Java framework.”. For a newcomer I found it difficult to get a good overview about all the concepts introduced in genetic algorithms. Before diving into JGAP, I think it is essential that these concepts are well understood.
title: Introduction to genetic algorithms

summary:
I have been developing software professionally since 2001. Helping customers with solutions that really add value. I like a challenge and continuously keep my knowledge up to date and share it with great enthusiasm to the public and with my team.
Since 2012 I have been designing and developing backend and mobile applications for organisations with user bases of several hundred of thousands to millions of users. From high performance backend systems which run on AWS to native Android apps for consumers.
